message.content:
cs.DC, cs.DS, cs.NI, cs.SI, cs.IT

Reasoning: The paper deals with distributed computing in a broadcast network, where nodes have limited information and communication capabilities. This suggests that the paper could belong to the Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing (cs.DC) sub-category. The problem of computing a maximal independent set (MIS) is a classic problem in distributed computing, and the paper proposes several algorithms to solve it in different variants of the broadcast model. This suggests that the paper could also belong to the Data Structures and Algorithms (cs.DS) sub-category. The paper also deals with network information (or lack thereof) and connectivity, which suggests that it could belong to the Networking and Internet Architecture (cs.NI) sub-category. The paper proposes algorithms that rely on carrier sensing and collision detection, which suggests that it could belong to the Signal Processing (cs.SI) sub-category. Finally, the paper proposes algorithms that rely on time synchronization, which suggests that it could belong to the Information Theory (cs.IT) sub-category.
